comments.commentBody: Cancer was non existent in most societies because aside from a few forms, it is a disease of aging.  People in traditional societies didn't live long enough to get it.  They died before age 50 for the most part.

"The China Study" has been debunked as yet more crank nonsense.

But it's true that SAD is responsible for a lot of illness, and not just cancers, but heart disease, ulcers, colitis, food allergies, other autoimmune disorders and a host of other maladies.

Many doctors sincerely believe screening by mammography does reduce cancer deaths.  This article merely excludes screening by mammography from the short list of screening tests which has been shown in studies to have reduced cancer deaths.  This puts mammography screening a category something like that of blood letting in the 18th century; widely believed to be good for the patient, but not yet proven to be so.  Hopefully, it will not ulitmately prove to be no more effective than blood letting, but, the wide belief of doctors in the effectiveness of a procedure is no guarantee.
Yikes! Regulate carcinogens! You won't want to introduce more " job killing Federal regulations would you?

You are simply wrong that learning about cancer earlier rather than later is ineffective.  This is scary that anyone has the gall to suggest otherwise.  Logic should enter into this discussion.  A cancer caught early definitely leads to better cures than a cancer at the latest stage.  I don't care what your surveys or research studies say.
The ideal is to die of old age or natural causes, and not have to suffer through cancer and its treatment.  The war on cancer is a necessary one.
Ingesting pesticides is definitely a big health problem.
Please cite data for "warped proteins" in foods from GMO crops.

Resveratol research is controversial and much of the earlier research was discounted research is more promising but not necessarily for cancer.  Interestingly, resveratrol has been determined to bind to estrogen receptors similar to BPA.
I cite Alimta from Lilly, effective against some lung and other cancers.

It might be helpful if discussion became more specific rather than referral to "cancer," which if I am not mistaken can be any one of about one hundred diseases.  Put that way, finding the keys to unlocking the mysteries is seen in its proper perspective.  Yes, cells go wild and reproduce themselves without interference:  but no, it all does not happen in exactly the same way, and that's the rub.

If you read these pages (and comments) regularly you will find the pattern you describe in every case. People read the article, but take in little content. They simply persist in their preconceived notions about health, which are mostly based on magical thinking and what they have picked up at the University of Google. Science education is in an abysmal state; quacks and conspiracists of all types have seized on the internet as the newest way to peddle their crank ideas.

You will also notice if you read regularly that comments such as yours get a couple of “recommends” while the ones that claim (fill in the blank) prevents all or that present various conspiracies about medicine and pharmaceuticals are extremely popular.

As a research scientist who does not work on cancer but follows the work closely, I found the article interesting and mildly depressing, but many of the comments are profoundly depressing. It is very clear that many people cannot comprehend the complexity of understanding and treating a disease like cancer. I agree that lifestyle changes will be enormously beneficial. They will reduce but not eliminate the terrible toll of cancer.

A reasonable metaphor might be to imagine what would have happened if European explorers were set out on on overland trip from the east coast to the Pacific in 1493. In fact, it would be over another 300 years before the understanding and capability existed to carry out such a trip. I am constantly amazed at how much we have learned about normal cells and cancer cells since 1968. That knowledge is now ready to be harnessed. I may be a foolish optimist, but I do believe that we are near to rational treatments of several cancers if we stay the course.

@ janet: "If we don't stand up for each other against the 0.1% who control capital, we will be at each other's throats for the crumbs."

Thanks for your post. I moved to Munich from the US 8 years ago to start what is now a thriving small (very small) business. Reading American commentary from this vantage point has been enlightening, to say the least. I agree somewhat with Professor Krugman's view of German attitudes. Just yesterday a customer talked to me about "lazy Mediterraneans peeling olives in the midday sun." But the truth is that the main reason Europe finds itself in its present straits is, as you put it in different terms, that its banks followed too closely the American model, not to mention Goldman Sachs' 3-Card Monte hustle it pulled on Greece, which is strangely left out of the current discussions. The sooner the US can get out from under its Tea Party paralysis, the better off the world's economies will be.

Tim,

I too have lived and worked in both Europe and North America and I fear that you are painting an entirely incorrect picture. When one country, Germany, has youth unemployment of just 7.9% and another, Greece, has a rate of 57.9%, this is not a gentle bit of bickering in an otherwise united family. It is a catastrophe which will cause trouble for decades.

I wouldn't call the economic and social conditions in Greece and Spain to be "taking place within what the US would call the middle ground".

That's one the main points of Prof. Krugman's article. Viewed through the lense of Denmark, or any other successful northern Europe country, this is just "bickering". For the Greeks, Spaniards, Portuguese, and to a lesser extent the Italian, who are seeing their countries' economic and social fabric being torn apart, this is a matter of survival.

I am an American who has lived and worked in Denmark for half my life. I just returned from a visit to Spain, I work with an Italian WHO official living here, do work for companies in various EU countries and get paid in both Euros and in Danish Kroner. I recently visited family in California and have interests on both sides of the Atlantic.

I write this as prelude to my opinion that I find so much commentary and reaction by US journalists and readers is tainted by the extreme financial conflicts and divisions one does not see here. Yes, there are regional differences in policy and banking, but it all takes place within what the US would call middle ground.

The Euro is not on its deathbed. Europeans bicker amongst themselves but are solid in their opposition to what they've seen take place in the US, and they will find a way out of their present troubles which were partly self inflicted but mostly caused by the US capital markets and their toxic derivatives that brought Europe to its knees.

Now that same body is attempting to bully their EU neighbors who are struggling to address unemployment and get back on their feet. The economies of the EU would be far better off if the US could somehow get its own act together . but that may not come soon enough.

I agree on the liability issue. Making an announcement may cause passengers with nut allergies to have a false sense of security that the airline will ensure compliance with the request, when airlines do not have the resources or the ability to do so. It opens up a whole can of worms. I would have no problem abstaining from peanuts for a few hours (just as I, like you, pack a nut-free lunch for my daughter every day because other kids in her class have nut allergies), but the airline cannot enforce this with all passengers.

But I agree that a clear policy, stated up front and enforced at the front lines, is necessary so that passengers will know what to expect each time they fly. Having such a hodge-podge policy creates a PR nightmare for the airline at best, and liability at worst.

But I think I will make sure not to pack a peanut butter sandwich for future flights. I've never though about this issue before.

I think if I were the person responsible for this issue at an airline, I would:

1) Definitely want a consistent policy, well advertised, making it clear what the airline will do and that it cannot limit exposure beyond that

2) Allow allergic adults/parents to board early to wipe down their rows

3) Have flight attendants reseat passengers in the row (same side of the aisle) if necessary to allow that row to be nut free.

I don't think I would allow the announcements, because the need for an announcement suggests that the person is sensitive to airborne allergens, and the airline cannot guarantee compliance. It makes me uncomfortable (and possibly raises liability issues?) to put a person's safety in the hands of so many people who may or may not comply. Unfortunately, I think if the allergic person would need all passengers on the plane to refrain from opening or eating a nut product, that's beyond the ability of the airline to establish and the announcement creates only a false sense of security.

As an individual, I would have no problem refraining from eating nut products if I heard such an announcement; just as I have no problem with nut bans at my (non-allergic) son's school. But from the standpoint of what an airline can do and what responsibility it can take on, I think it's different matter.

It's a hard topic and I really feel for the families with allergies,, though.

Obviously the Euro is "sustainable". That's the wrong question. The question is whether it is desirable, and the answer, for ordinary people in all countries of the EU, is "no".

Europe's real problem is that the elites are completely separated from ordinary people, even more so than in the USA. The top governing body of the EU is the European Commission, which is not elected. NYT readers complain about the Senate and the House, but at least every member of those bodies has to face the voters periodically.

Martin Wolf, the Financial Times economics editor, in a comment to one of his columns put his personal estimate on the sustainability of the euro currency zone at "50-50."

There are deep-seated cultural differences on how a political society should work among different countries of the euro zone. Turns out deep-seated cultural differences drive political policy drive economic policy.

Will European political elites lead the discussion on how a possible two-currency zone (a Latin euro and a Nordic euro) might be fashioned out of today's one-currency zone? Would the voters pay any attention to this "leadership."

Marine Le Pen, your close-up awaits.

@Bryan, it looks like nobody responded to your primary point, which is a shame. As with every federal law, the legislation itself provides what is best described as a framework. Once the law is passed, the dirty work of creating the administrative regulations necessary to actually implement the law begins. That is wholly within the purview of the Executive Branch, which is required only to stay within the confines of the framework the law has created.

I do not know the language of the ACA well enough off the top of my head to tell you whether Mr. Obama has the power to make this particular modification unilaterally, through changes to the regulations. However, I do know enough about laws and regulations to know that it's far more likely that he can than that he cannot.

I fail to find just what you consider "has hurt to the quick so many American families.  Those policies who providers mailed cancellations for had enormous deductibles--from $10,000 to $25,000 and huge co-pays and many did not cover hospitalization.  The companies, motives, however, were less than pure.  Knowing these policies would not meet  the higher standards of the ACA, they quickly disassociated themselves.  This was a group of approximately 5 million Americans.  Yes, the President should never have made such an "allness" statement but at the time the ACA became law in 2010, this was common knowledge.  Did those insurers use the time intervening to amend their less-than-quality policies?  Are we not still dealing with one of the most capricious industries in this country?  And they thrive because rarely do people buy policies when they are ill.  I do hope his move saves Democrats whose coattails of the President they've been willing to ride as long as they were comfortable.  "Compassionate conservatism" didn't do much for us during Dubya's administration.

Those same nations have managed in the last 100 years to kill over 100 Million of their and our Citizens through malfeasance at a criminal level. Since they are the "Shining Light" should we also follow that example as well?

The selectivity with which you write this editorial is truly remarkable; whereas you clearly state support for the position embraced by President Obama, you neglect to mention the fact that he is the chief executive of our wonderful United States of America, who is obliged to implement the bills which Congress has enacted and he has signed into law, and has no power under the Constitution to arbitrarily change that law without the consent of Congress, which he has not yet sought.

President Obama should know better since he is a self described, and widely accepted to be, Constitutional scholar. The House of Representatives hold the purse strings of the nation and they will soon debate proposed bills and amendments pertaining to the now, Un-Affordable Care Act, also widely known as Obamacare.

That President Obama had the class to, as described by The New York Times on Thursday, to appear "contrite", a word I understand he never used in his address, is just wonderful. That he accepted responsibility for this debacle of a "train wreck" which has hurt to the quick so many American families is laudable. That it is simply a political ploy is certain. Democrats have, led by President Clinton, distanced themselves from his newly acquired position, which simply does not work at all on the Constitutional level, and is strictly a political tactic in an attempt to save Democrats who will face the voters in the 2014 elections.

We, the citizens, of this great nation, deserve better.

Transporting someone in such a debilitated condition involves a lot of jostling, noise, bright lights, etc., and would probably not be very pleasant for them.  (And they'd be just as likely to die in the ambulance as at home).

"taken off the ventilator and made comfortable. He died peacefully on Sunday night. "

Any chance that included getting him home to an actual human kind of bed and room?
My hero as well.  Why do we put humans through things we would never inflict on a loved pet?

Like you, I've had a good life.
In the end I want a good death.

I am now 89 and getting paliative care for my terminal prostate cancer. I would like to have this Doctor take me out when I request it. Knowing its possible to pick my death would be greaat. At 86, going into my 3d act I wrote my autobiography "Confessions of a Criminologist." I had no interest in anyone else reading my memoir; however, it was great for me in my forced retirement to review my life. At the risk of being megalomaniacal (which I am) what a fascinating life I have had. Now at 89 all of my memories including my life as a sailor in WW2 are treasures that I recall with appropriate music like Sinatra, Billy Holiday, and Billy Esckstine. (Not the crappy supid rap and other current screamings.) All of these recollections make my 3d Act pleasant.

I was wondering why the patient went to the hospital in the first place. If you don't want treatment, don't go to the hospital. They aren't going to just give you a lollipop and send you home. They treat people's medical conditions. They DO PROCEDURES. They shove breathing tubes down your throat. They cut you open. They give you meds. That's what they do.

If you don't want to be treated, don't go to the hospital.

Be very careful what you wish for.
Great palliative care should not be synonymous to withdrawing life-sustaining care. The image of a breathing tube "thrust" down a "raw" airway is the kind of language that is designed to convince "the family" that this is all pure suffering, for no good reason or purpose. What if the colleague who wanted to "keep him going" was actually the one who had spoken with the patient? Who is the patient's advocate here, and who is making assumptions about quality of life and prognosis?
